data.text:
Tena Richuisa, 82

MENIFEE — Tena Carmella Natale Richuisa, 82, died Friday, Oct.17, 2003, at Menifee Valley Medical Center in Sun City.

Born May 25, 1921, in Providence, R.I., she was a homemaker for57 years. She was a volunteer and secretary at the Perris SeniorCenter. She was a dietician for the Fountain Blue ConvalescentHospital in Anaheim for 15 years.

Mrs. Richuisa is survived by her husband, Anthony Richuisa ofMenifee; sons Skip Richuisa of Menifee and Joe Richuisa of Cypress;daughter, Karen Bevans of Santa Ana; sisters Dolores Curtis ofMurrieta and Sue Curci of Warwick, R.I.; four grandchildren; andthree great-grandchildren.

Visitation is scheduled from 4 to 7 p.m. and rosary recited from7 to 8 p.m. Thursday, Oct. 23, at Miller-Jones Mortuary &Crematory in Sun City. A Mass will be celebrated at 11 a.m. Friday,Oct. 24, at St. Vincent’s Ferrer Catholic Church with the Rev.Antonio Das Neves officiating. Interment will be at RiversideNational Cemetery.

Miller-Jones Mortuary & Crematory in Sun City is handlingarrangements.

Delores Johnson, 70

SUN CITY — Dolores Ramona Johnson, 70, died Tuesday, Oct. 14,2003, at Menifee Valley Medical Center.

Born Sept. 29, 1933, in Plummer, Idaho, she lived in Sun Cityfor 15 years. She was an executive legal secretary for more than 40years, retiring from Federal Savings and Loan Association. Shegraduated from Caldwell High School in 1951 and Cal State L.A. in1972 with a degree in American studies. She enjoyed baseball,football and crocheting afghans.

Mrs. Johnson was preceded in death by her son, David Johnson;and daughter, Mary Leslie. She is survived by her husband, WayneJohnson of Sun City; daughters Sherry Kittrell of Huntington Beachand Kathi Kemmis of Temecula; sisters Janice Low of Temple City andAramae Eurton of Valencia; and eight grandchildren.

A memorial service is scheduled for 10 a.m. Saturday, Oct. 25,at Miller-Jones Mortuary & Crematory in Sun City.

Miller-Jones Mortuary & Crematory in Sun City is handlingarrangements.

LaVon Grundvig, 90

SUN CITY — LaVon Best Grundvig, 90, died Friday, Oct. 17, 2003,in Temecula.

Born July 20, 1913, in Salt Lake City, she lived in Sun City for36 years. She was a homemaker. She was a member of the FaithLutheran Church and Retired Officers Association.

Mrs. Grundvig is survived by her daughter, Sandra G. Adams ofTemecula; sons Daniel Alfred Grundvig of Flagler Beach, Fla.,Robert Hugh Grundvig of Oroville and Peter Ashley Grundvig ofBoise, Idaho; 12 grandchildren; and 13 great-grandchildren.

The family suggests donations to a hospice of choice.

Private family services are planned.

Evans-Brown Mortuary in Sun City is handling arrangements.

M.D. “Bill” Benson, 83

TEMECULA — Maurice Danforth “Bill” Benson, 83, died Thursday,Oct. 9, 2003, at Rancho Springs Medical Center in Murrieta.

Born Aug. 29, 1920, in Hannaford, N.D., he lived in Temecula for20 years. He was a sales manager for the 3M Company for 35 years.He was a volunteer of the Temecula Chamber of Commerce and ABCPreschool in Temecula. He enjoyed woodworking and westernmemorabilia.

Mr. Benson is survived by his sons and daughters-in-law, Johnand Sharon Benson of Lake Forest and Thomas and Debra Benson ofTucson, Ariz.; daughter, Karen Benson of Oxnard; sister, GwenNottingham of Laurel, Mont.; three grandchildren; and twogreat-grandchildren.

A memorial service is scheduled for 11 a.m. Friday, Oct. 24, atMurrieta United Methodist Church.

Valley Funeral Home is handling arrangements.

Anthony Janik, 88

VISTA – Anthony Alexander Janik, 88, died Thursday, Oct. 16,2003, at his home.

Born Oct. 24, 1914, in Toledo, Ohio, he lived in Vista for 26years. He was a warehouse manager. He served in the U.S. Navy.

Mr. Janik is survived by his daughters, Marie McCourt of Bishop,Arlene Gagnon of Henderson, Nev., and Diane Nielsen of Vista; fivegrandchildren; five great-grandchildren; and threegreat-great-grandchildren.

A Mass will be celebrated at 9:30 a.m. Thursday, Oct. 23, atMission San Luis Rey Chapel in Oceanside. Private inurnment atWestminster Memorial Park in Westminster is planned.

Eternal Hills Mortuary is handling arrangements.

Laura Coldren, 86

ESCONDIDO – Laura Margaret Coldren, 86, died Sunday, Oct. 19,2003, at her home of heart failure.

Born May 17, 1917, in Tecumseh, Okla., she lived in Escondidofor four years. She was a schoolteacher from 1958 to 1960 for theSan Juaquin County School System and from 1960 to 1980 for theStockton Unified School District. She graduated from the Universityof the Pacific in 1958. She was a member of the First MethodistChurch in Escondido and a life member of San Diego RockhopperVolkmarch Club.

Mrs. Coldren was preceded in death by Ilam Maine Coldren in2002, James Walter Surber in 1962, Mable Clair Lyon in 1952,Mildred Clair Surber Hammons in 1972, James Walter Surber Jr. in1998, Mary Jane Surber Hoffman in 1997, Ruth Ann Suber Taylor in1995 and Roy John Surber in 2002. She is survived by her daughterand son-in-law, Julia and Kenneth Paul Walker of Berwyn Heights,Md., and Laurie Wood of San Diego; brother and sister-in-law Carland Carol Surber of Ruidoso, N.M.; sisters and brother-in-law NevaLouise Slater of Manchester, Conn., Dorothy Pearl and Bill Yardy ofOklahoma City and Lee Arden Lyon of San Marcos, Texas; andgrandchildren Scott and Heather Wood.

A memorial service is scheduled for Saturday, Nov. 1, at theFirst Methodist Church in Escondido. Burial at sea is planned.

The family suggests donations to the San Diego ZoologicalSociety, PO Box 551, San Diego, CA 92112.

Daniel Barry Sr., 84

VISTA – Daniel Joseph Barry Sr., 84, died Saturday, Oct. 18,2003, at Tri-City Medical Center in Oceanside of heart failure.

Born Feb. 2, 1919, in Pasadena, he lived in Vista for 49 years.He was a technician with Pacific Bell for more than 30 years. Heserved in the U.S. Marine Corps during World War II incommunications. He was a member of St. Francis of Assisi CatholicChurch in Vista, the Knights of Columbus, the Boy Scouts ofAmerica, Los Californianos, the Oceanside Harbor Flotilla, and 16-6of the U.S. Coast Guard Auxiliary. He was an eighth-generationnative Californian.

Mr. Barry was preceded in death by his wife of 59 years, BettyJ. Barry, in January 2003. He is survived by his sons, Daniel J.Barry Jr. and Bruce Barry, both of Vista, and Brian Barry of Texas;daughter and son-in-law Nancy and Jim Parker of Vista; threegrandchildren; and three great-grandchildren.

Private family services with interment at Eternal Hills MemorialPark in Vista are planned.

Allen Bros. Mortuary, Vista Chapel is handling arrangements.

Mildred French, 99

ESCONDIDO – Mildred B. French, 99, died Friday, Oct. 17, 2003,at Life Care Center of Escondido of natural causes.

Born June 28, 1904, in Spring Valley, Minn., she lived atLawrence Welk Village in Escondido for 32 years. She was a pianoteacher. She graduated from MacPhails School of Music inMinneapolis, and taught there for many years. She taught privatelessons for 20 years in San Jose. She played on the radio and intheaters for silent movies. She was a featured pianist for theMinneapolis Symphony Orchestra. She was a lifelong member of theRosicrucian Order AMORC.

Mrs. French was preceded in death by her husband of 69 years,James B. French, Jan. 18, 2000. She is survived by many nieces andnephews; and caregivers Ernie Liebman and Sokhouy Casey, both ofEscondido.

A memorial service is scheduled for 1 p.m. Sunday, Nov. 9, atLawrence Welk Village Hall, 8975 Lawrence Welk Drive in Escondidowith Ernie Liebman officiating. Her cremains will be scattered.

Donations are suggested to San Diego Hospice, 4311 Third Ave.,San Diego, CA 92103-1407.

Joe Moreno, 52

CARLSBAD – Joe G. Moreno, 52, died Sunday, Oct. 19, 2003.

Born May 19, 1951, in Escondido, he lived in Carlsbad all hislife. He was a locker room attendant at the La Costa Resort &Spa. He was a member of St. Patrick Catholic Church in Carlsbad. Heenjoyed saltwater fishing and golf.

Mr. Moreno is survived by his parents, Mary F. and Jose M.Moreno of Carlsbad; brothers and sisters-in-law Thomas and PaulaMoreno of Oceanside, Frank and Kathy Moreno of Vista and JohnMoreno of Carlsbad; sisters and brothers-in-law Rose Sperry, IreneMoreno and Barbara Moreno, all of Carlsbad, and Carol Moreno andChristine and Jason Matthews, all of Oceanside; and 12 nieces andnephews.

Visitation is scheduled from 5 to 7 p.m. and rosary recited at 7p.m. today, Oct. 22, at St. Patrick’s Church, 3821 Adams St. inCarlsbad with the Rev. Steve McCall officiating. A Mass will becelebrated at 10 a.m. Thursday, Oct. 23, at St. Patrick’s Churchwith the Rev. McCall officiating. His cremains will be scattered atsea.

The family suggests donations to St. Patrick’s Catholic Church,3821 Adams St., Carlsbad, CA 92008.

Oceanside Mortuary is handling arrangements.

Lisa Jenkins, 39

VALLEY CENTER – Lisa Marie Jenkins, 39, died Saturday, Oct. 18,2003, in an accident.

Born July 15, 1964, in California, she lived in Valley Centerfor 16 years. She was a homemaker.

Mrs. Jenkins is survived by her husband of 15 years, GregJenkins of Valley Center; mother Pat Glasscock of Alabama; fatherJames Lewallen of Oklahoma; son Dustin Jenkins of Valley Center;and daughters Lacey Jenkins and Shelby Jenkins, both of ValleyCenter.

A memorial service is scheduled for 11 a.m. Friday, Oct. 24, atRidgeview Church, 28094 Lake Wolford Road in Valley Center withBill Trok officiating.

McLeod Mortuary is handling arrangements.

Alma McDowell, 76

FALLBROOK – Alma L. McDowell, 76, died Monday, Oct. 20, 2003, inEscondido.

Born Jan. 3, 1927, in Hope, Ark., she lived in Fallbrook for 65years. She was a homemaker for 60 years.

Mrs. McDowell was preceded in death by her husband, ChesterMcDowell, in 2001; and daughter Caroline Murray in 1998.

She is survived by her sons and daughters-in-law, DwayneMcDowell of Bayfield, Colo., Richard and Lynanne McDowell ofFallbrook, Allen and Lynn McDowell of Escondido and Lee and RosendaMcDowell of Fallbrook; daughter and son-in-law Linda and RobertRivera of Platias, N.M.; sister Patricia McDowell of Fallbrook; 12grandchildren; and 10 great-grandchildren.

Private family memorial services will be held. Private cremationis planned.

The family suggests donations to the Joslyn Senior CitizenCenter, 399 Heald Lane, Fallbrook, CA 92028.

Berry-Bell & Hall Fallbrook Mortuary is handlingarrangements.

Shelby Escoffier, 12

CARLSBAD – Shelby Leigh Escoffier, 12, died Saturday, Oct. 18,2003, at her home of Rett Syndrome.

Born May 24, 1991, in Oceanside, she lived in Carlsbad all herlife.

Miss Escoffier is survived by her parents, Donna and ChipEscoffier of Carlsbad; and brother Troy Escoffier of Carlsbad.

A memorial service is scheduled for 5:30 p.m. Thursday, Oct. 23,at Daybreak Community Church, 6515 Ambrosia Lane in Carlsbad withDr. Dan Grider officiating.

Her cremains will be scattered at sea.

The family suggests donations to the Harvestland Children’sMinistries, Daybreak Community Church, 6515 Ambrosia Lane,Carlsbad, CA 92009.

Accu-Care Cremation Center is handling arrangements.

Irene Smith, 98

FALLBROOK – Irene Smith, 98, died Sunday, Oct. 19, 2003.

Born July 23, 1905, in Fredrick Town, Mo., she lived inFallbrook for 26 years.

Mrs. Smith was preceded in death by her husband, John J. Smith,in 1984.

She is survived by her daughter, Rita Boule of Fallbrook;grandchildren Marc, Paige and Dean; and twogreat-grandchildren.

Eternal Hills Mortuary is handling arrangements.

Ruth Gray, 82

ESCONDIDO – Ruth Gray, 82, died Wednesday, Oct. 15, 2003, at herhome.

Born Dec. 25, 1920, in Fort Smith, Ark., she lived in Escondidofor 32 years. She was a homemaker.

Mrs. Gray is survived by her son, Robert F. Gray Jr. ofEscondido; daughter and son-in-law Patricia and Phillip Sidnam ofPortage, Mich.; brother Walter M. Woods of W. Jordan, Utah;grandchildren Sean, Robert, Mark, Christine, Teresa and Melissa;and 13 great-grandchildren.

A memorial service is scheduled for 3 p.m. Saturday, Oct. 25, atAlhiser-Comer Mortuary, 225 S. Broadway in Escondido.

Alhiser-Comer Mortuary is handling arrangements.

Robert Wollter, 81

ESCONDIDO – Robert Gustav “Bob” Wollter, 81, died Friday, Oct.17, 2003, at Palomar Medical Center.

Born Feb. 27, 1922, in Youngstown, Ohio, he lived in Escondidofor 32 years. He was a singer, dancer and actor in nightclubs andtelevision for 14 years. He served in the U.S. Army during WorldWar II as a Chinese language interpreter. He helped foundInterfaith Community Services through First United MethodistChurch. He was a toastmaster for 25 years.

Mr. Wollter is survived by his wife of 52 years, Ruth Wollter ofEscondido; son Dana Wollter of Escondido; daughters and sons-in-lawKimberlee Wollter and Tom Titus of Eugene, Ore., and Robin and JoshEvans of San Diego; and grandchildren Alex, Laurel and Julia.

A memorial service is scheduled for 2 p.m. Saturday, Oct. 25, atFirst United Methodist Church, 341 S. Kalmia in Escondido. Privateinurnment will be at First United Methodist Church Columbarium.

Alhiser-Comer Mortuary is handling arrangements.

Patricia Neely, 65

SAN JACINTO – Patricia Lucille Neely, 65, died Saturday, Oct.18, 2003, at Hemet Valley Medical Center.

Born April 30, 1938, in Roanoke, Va., she lived in Hemet for sixmonths. She lived in Oceanside 25 years previously. She was ahomemaker.

Mrs. Neely is survived by her daughters and son-in-law, JanaeWalton of San Jacinto and Christine and Michael Arkin of Okinawa,Japan; sons and daughter-in-law Robert and Sally Neely of WarnerRobbins, Ga., and Steven Neely of Arizona; and grandchildrenBenjamen, Emily, Kevin and Katherine.

Private family services and inurnment are planned.

Cremation Society of Riverside County is handlingarrangements.

Roy Laremore, 88

SAN MARCOS – Roy A. Laremore, 88, died Sunday, Oct. 19,2003.

Born July 21, 1915, in St. Louis, Mo., he lived in San Marcosfor 30 years. He worked for the Los Angeles County Fire Departmentfor 27 years.

He served in the U.S. Navy during World War II. He was a 50-yearmember of the Elks Club.

Mr. Laremore was preceded in death by his wife of 33 years,Connie Laremore, in 1986; and brother Bill Laremore.

He is survived by his son, Mike Laremore; stepson DaleBrittingham of Mesquite, Nev.; stepdaughters and sons-in-law Helenand Dave Orkin of San Marcos and Loretta and Jerry Dewey of LaHabra; four grandchildren; and 10 great-grandchildren.

Eternal Hills Mortuary is handling arrangements.

Maxine Schirk, 69

CARLSBAD – Maxine Schirk, 69, died Friday, Oct. 3, 2003, at herhome of cancer.

Born March 17, 1934, in Michigan, she lived in Carlsbad for 27years.

Mrs. Schirk is survived by her son and daughter-in-law, Carl andLena Carpenter of Vista; daughter and son-in-law Kit and Mike Rosiaof St. George, Utah; brother and sister-in-law Daniel and GeneKline of Florida; sister and brother-in-law Mary Jane and GeorgeHollabough of Michigan; and grandchildren Greg, Beau, Shane,Brianna and Trevor.

A memorial service is scheduled for 1 p.m. Monday, Nov. 3, atSt. Michael’s Church in Poway with Monsignor Dolan officiating.Burial will follow at 2 p.m. at Dearborn Memorial Park in Powaywith Monsignor Dolan officiating. Private cremation is planned.

Accu-Care Cremation Center is handling arrangements.

Lila LaChusa, 87

MESA GRANDE INDIAN RESERVATION – Lila ” The General” LaChusa,87, died Saturday, Oct. 18, 2003, at her home.

Born Sept. 28, 1916, in Riverside, she lived at Mesa GrandeIndian Reservation all her life. She was a member of the MesaGrande Band of Mission Indians and the Santa Ysabel Mission Church.She had a bachelor’s degree in nursing and was a nurse for morethan 30 years. She enjoyed reading and horses.

Mrs. LaChusa was preceded in death by her son, Raymond LaChusa,in 1968.

She is survived by her daughters, Rae Ann Lafferty, Pixi Valleand D’lorah Montieth; grandchildren Raymond, Rising Son, GreyEagle, Andrea, Samantha, Sha-na-na, Paul, Mike, Jimmy, Danny,Edward, David, Nick, Norma Lynn, Melissa Rose, Lynda, Nancy Jean,Teresa and Adena; and more than 25 great-grandchildren.

Viewing with an overnight vigil will be held starting at 6:30p.m. Friday, Oct. 24, at the Mesa Grande Indian Reservation. A Masswill be celebrated at 10 a.m. Saturday, Oct. 25, at Santa YsabelMission Church with the Rev. Dennis O’Conner officiating. Burialwill follow on the Mesa Grande Indian Reservation.

Bonham Bros. & Stewart Mortuary in Ramona is handlingarrangements.

Matthew Saccomanno Jr., 69

OCEANSIDE – Matthew Saccomanno Jr., 69, died Saturday, Oct. 18,2003 of natural causes.

He was born Dec. 21, 1933, in Camden, N.J. He retired in 1991from the U.S. Marine Corps as a sergeant major. He was a member ofthe Elks Lodge 1561, and North County Model Railroad TrainSociety.

Mr. Saccomanno is survived by his wife of 47 years, JoAnneSaccomanno of Oceanside; son and daughter-in-law Matthew III andMargi Saccomanno of Oceanside; daughters and sons-in-law Diane andMarty Koeth of Tehachapi, Patricia Brown of Capistrano Beach andJanet and Gerald Edwards of Sacramento; brothers and sisters-in-lawRichard and Nancy Saccomanno of Marlton, N.J., and Anthony and PatSaccomanno of Cherry Hill, N.J.; and grandchildren Brandon, MatthewIV, Evan, Kristin, Sarah, Joshua, Jamie and Andy.

A memorial service is scheduled for 11:30 a.m. Friday, Oct. 24,at the Marine Memorial Chapel, Building 1161, Mainside on CampPendleton.

The family suggests donations to the Hospice of the North Coast,5441 Avenida Encinas, Suite A, Carlsbad, CA 92008.

Accu-Care Cremation Center is handling arrangements.

Memorials

Marshall Hall McCrummen

Marshall Hall McCrummen passed away peacefully at his Lake SanMarcos home on Wednesday, October 15, 2003, with his wife by hisside after a brief but courageous battle with cancer.

Marshall was born on September 24, 1941, in Lubbock, Texas.Marshal was a gifted athlete who excelled in track and field. Hegraduated with his accounting degree from Texas Tech University in1965 and went on to earn his CPA certification.

In 1975, he married his wife, Barbara and also became a fatherto her 11-year-old daughter, Kiki. Marshall had his own CPApractice for many years in Dallas and relocated to Laguna Niguel in1986.

Marshall and Barbara moved to the San Marcos area in 1998, wherehe continued his practice.

Marshall’s life was marked by his faith in God. His kindness,gentleness and compassion for others made him a friend to many. Hewas a devoted husband and father with a great sense of humor and anever-ending supply of patience, support and love.

Marshall is survived by his wife, Barbara; his mother, Marydell;his brothers, Lindsey and Roger; his daughter and son-in-law,Kirsten “Kiki” and Michael Oleson, along with his granddaughter,Darby; and his daughter and son-in-law Tamara and Chris Caballero.He is preceded in death by his father, Luther Hall McCrummen.

“I have fought the good fight. I have kept the faith. Now thereis in store for me the crown of righteousness which the Lord, therighteous Judge, will award to me on that day.” 2 Timothy4:7-8.

For those that knew and loved Marshall, grief over his absencewill be very real and deep. But so will the rejoicing at thethought of him standing in the presence of Jesus hearing the words,”Well done, my good and faithful servant!” This was a life thatwill continue to be celebrated as his legacy of faith is lived outin those he leaves behind.

A memorial service will take place on Friday, October 24, at 1p.m. at North Coast Calvary Chapel located at 7188 Avenida Encinasin Carlsbad.

In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to ElizabethHospice, 150 W. Crest St., Escondido, CA 92025 or North CoastCalvary Church Benevolent Fund, 7188 Avenida Encinas, Carlsbad,CA.

California Funeral Alternatives in Escondido is handlingarrangements.

Joe E. Sims

Joe E. Sims died peacefully at his home on October 17, 2003,surrounded by his loving family.

Joe was born June 26, 1924, near Post, Texas. In 1927 his familymade the long trip to Carlsbad, California, where they settled andwhere Joe lived most of his life.

A U.S. Army veteran of WWII, he served in the Pacific Theatreafter graduating from Oceanside-Carlsbad High School in 1942. Formany years after the war he owned his own business, Armstrong andSims in Oceanside. Joe was a charter member of the Moose Lodge,1325 and a lifetime member of the Elks Lodge 1561.

Joe is survived by his wife of 60 years, Alyce M. Sims and hisfamily, Mike and Sue Sims of Vista, Anne and Chandler Billeter ofVista, Joda and Dan Glassey of Carlsbad, Amy and Dean Adams ofOceanside, Jennifer Glassey of Oceanside, Jessica and Molly Sims ofVista and Joseph and Miles Billeter of Vista. In addition, he issurvived by his brothers and sisters, Faye Trotter of Oceanside,Joy Johns of Oceanside, Sonny Sims of Carlsbad, Marilyn Heistermanof Carlsbad, Bert and Joanna Sims of Vista, and many nieces andnephews.

A memorial service is planned for 10:30 a.m. on Saturday,October 25, 2003, at the All Saint’s Cemetery in San Luis ReyValley with a celebration of Joe’s life to follow next door atHeritage Park.

In lieu of flowers, the family requests that a memorial donationin Joe’s name be made to Tri-City Hospice, 2095 W. Vista Way, Suite217, Vista, CA 92083 or the Alzheimer’s Disease Research, PO Box1950, Clarksburg, Md 20871-1950.

In Memoriam

An Only Child

Angel on the Christmas tree,

Icing on the cake,

A diamond among lumps of coal.

Moonbeams on the lake,

First bright star I see tonight,

Every dream come true,

Cliches aside, most of all,

I loved that you were you.

Michelle Jean Welser

7-16-76 – 10-22-93

Seventeen years we had

together

Before the Universe

Opened its gaping mouth

For one terrible moment

And took you away forever.

I liked to call you

“My one perfect child.”

How you laughed at that!

Fresh and funny, you were

No respecter of the trite

Or doggerel verse.

Skilled beyond your years

In ways to make the words

Dance on the page

Or float along in images

Luminous as bubbles,

You were to be a poet.

Wise and honest,

You learned a lot

Those last five years.

From lonely twelve

You made the leap

To bright young woman.

What a joy you were to us all –

Friends, cousins, aunts, grandparents and me.

After ten years, your memory lives

In the lonely spot in our hearts.

Love,

Mom
